text:
Pell Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Mott Street, showing a portion of New York's Chinatown. View 2 is a photostatic reproduction of the original.

About 1900
No's. 1-2

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

View 1 View 2 - Neg. # 1168

(1)
Mott Street,north from Chatham Square. This view is looking Northward. The three buildings at the left are No's 17-19-and 21 Mott Street and are south of and adjoining the south west corner. The R.C. Church of the Transfiguration founded in 1827 occupies the north west corner. The original church at this location was the Zion Lutheran, which became the Zion Episcopal in 1810.
A fire destroyed that edifice in 1815, and was replaced by a new building in 1819. The present congregation purchased the property in 1853.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection,

(2)
The same.

Beecher Ogden,
No Reproduction.

(1)
Mott Street,north from Chatham Square. This view is looking Northward. The three buildings at the left are No's 17-19-and 21 Mott Street and are south of and adjoining the south west corner. The R.C. Church of the Transfiguration founded in 1827 occupies the north west corner. The original church at this location was the Zion Lutheran, which became the Zion Episcopal in 1810.
A fire destroyed that edifice in 1815, and was replaced by a new building in 1819. The present congregation purchased the property in 1853.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection,

(2)
The same.

Beecher Ogden,
No Reproduction.

(1)
Pell Street, east from Mott Street to the Bowery and showing a portion of that locality known as Chinatown. Midway between the aforementioned points is Doyers Street, a short winding thoroughfare from the Bowery. In the latter is the famous bend known as the Bloody Angle. Chinese restaurants and curiosity shops line the curb, while upstairs a teeming horde resides.
P. L. Sperr.
September 3, 1927.

(2)
The same, at a later date. Note the improvement to the building shown at the extreme left. This structure is at the N.E. corner of Mott and Pell Streets.
P. L. Sperr.
June 9, 1933.

(3)
Photographers vantage point for this view is at Doyers Street. In the left foreground is No. 12, a building that in the 90's housed a cabaret run by an individual known as Nigger Mike Salter. Irving Berlin, the famous songwriter, was employed here, subsequent to a similar engagement at the Chatham Club (No. 8 Doyers Street).
P. L. Sperr.
June 13, 1933.

About 1929.
Ewing Galloway.

A sugar cane vendor in Chinatown, near Mott and Pell Streets.

October 8, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Occupations - Peddlers - Food - Refreshments - Sugar cane.

text:
(1)
New Year's Celebration in Chinatown, before the On Leong Tong Club-rooms at No. 41 Mott Street, (building bearing flag). This view shows the spectators awaiting the approach of the parade.
February 11, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Another view northward on Mott Street at Pell Street and showing "Young China" leading the parade.
February 11, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The final halt at Tong Headquarters.
February 11, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Chinese New Year, No. 1-3.
